discourse_list.title: Unblocking the stalled short-term bonds revenues generating initiatives

content.content: So far we have at least two public projects that are delayed sine die by the situation at RWF-001: MIP65 and domain investigation work on Backed Finance. MIP65 at least has a target size of 500M DAI which would generate 15M per year or above 40k DAI per day at a 3% rate. Lack of legal funding is holding up similar deals with multi-billion $ organizations. Every day of delay has a 40-80k DAI opportunity cost. It is key to return to profitability (see ALM forecast). @christiancdpetersen and his team were kind enough to help us even after Christian resigned (and subsequently getting fired in an email) without any clear compensation. But Christian has had to face some unprofessional behavior and legal threats with implied community tolerance, which is understandably driving him away from a project he has helped put on the map for RWA. Moreover, legal advice from tier 1 firms is not cheap. We would normally be happy to fund legal expenses out of SF-001, but our budget expansion request was recently denied and we don’t have enough to finance these associated legal expenses out of our existing CU budget. I publicly asked the question to @williamr but got no answer so far. I understand that SF and others have reached out privately with simply no response. Every additional day that we waste continues to incur a very real opportunity cost ultimately only really borne by the token holder. My personal LLC is still a client of Latham and of Ogier. I propose that we leverage this existing relationship to avoid spending 2 months in KYC and explaining what a DAO is by onboarding a new entity. To avoid any endless fruitless discussion from trolls, I further propose that someone from GovAlpha, if they agree, be involved in all communications and be present in all the meetings to act as community observer, as they have a neutrality mandate and are well respected in the community. We would prefer not to issue an SPF request out of concern for the overall operating expense at the DAO and for timely execution. Therefore I ask @williamr to fund 500k DAI from the RWF legal budget (based on RWF legal cost expectations) to the SF-001 wallet to pay for legal fees we might have on ALM revenue-generating opportunities such as MIP65. Any excess will be refunded to RWF-001 and/or to the surplus buffer. Thanks @williamr for a prompt answer. In the continued absence of a response we will default to proposing an SPF adding weeks/months of delay to a very straightforward alternative costing 1-2 millions to MKR holders in opportunity cost.
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post is proposing a solution to unblock stalled short-term bonds revenue-generating initiatives. The proposal involves leveraging an existing relationship to avoid spending time onboarding a new entity and requesting funding from the RWF legal budget to pay for legal fees associated with revenue-generating opportunities. The post also includes constructive criticism of the delay and opportunity cost associated with the stalled projects, questions directed at @williamr, and a proposal for collaboration with GovAlpha.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal
None

content.content: I’ve read this 4 times and I still don’t fully understand what is being asked. Are you proposing that the DAO pays your own personal attorneys $500k to step in and act as the DAO’s legal counsel, and ban all DAO members except GovAlpha from attending calls with this new ad-hoc legal counsel? I just want to make sure I understand this correctly. Apologies if I’m not reading it right - please correct me wherever necessary.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: It is asking for funds to conduct legal domain work necessary to complete MIP65 and other projects. Mechanically, someone has to be the ‘client’ in order to mandate a legal firm. It would not transform the firm into an ad-hoc legal counsel. It is just a way of asking a legal firm to do a specific piece of work necessary in order to complete MIP65 and in order to provide an independent legal due diligence on the greenlit Backed Finance. The idea of asking GovAlpha to attend is to recognize that  Someone has to be the ‘client’ For expedience’s sakes Seb’s LLC is already a ‘client’ at several law firms the RWF has used in the past In order to remove any potential for impropriety that community members may allege (such as in your message) if they are uncomfortable with a contributor’s personal LLC mandating this work, GovAlpha be privy to all communication  Doesn’t have to be GovAlpha or even limited to anyone in particular, above was just a suggestion. The $500k figure is likely an overestimate but we used RWF’s costing in their original budget request. Personally my preference would be to return excess funds to the surplus buffer.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: I guess where I’m still a bit confused is how 1 CU can just make an aribtrary decision to send $500k of the DAOs money to another CU without any involvement from MKR governance. A few months as a delegate and I’m still trying to get my arms around how this DAO actually works. Is sending these massive amounts of money arbitrarily between CU members and to external law firms without any governance oversight just normal MakerDAO operations?     adcv:  In order to remove any potential for impropriety that community members may allege (such as in your message)   I have never alleged impropriety. I’ve only said that Maker allows for impropriety. I do not believe that the MakerDAO system should allow for any opacity which inevitably leads to impropriety. This forum post is a great example of that opacity.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: ChrisBlec:  I guess where I’m still a bit confused is how 1 CU can just make an aribtrary decision to send $500k of the DAOs money to another CU without any involvement from MKR governance.   I understand a bit better now. The RWF funds were approved by governance for the purpose of executing real-world finance transactions and risk assessments. In practice the MIP system asks for blanket approval to execute a mandate and then the core unit has discretion over the use of those funds up to the amount approved in the MIP. The safeguard is that token holders can retract approval at any time, though we can agree that the behavioral kink in this safeguard puts token holder funds at risk.     ChrisBlec:  I have never alleged impropriety. I’ve only said that Maker allows for impropriety. I do not believe that the MakerDAO system should allow for any opacity which inevitably leads to impropriety. This forum post is a great example of that opacity.   Think we can both agree. But for the purpose of executing on due diligence or legal work required for real-world transactions, in practice what we can do is involve more DAO actors to remove the potential for intransparency. I also don’t think this is a regular part of DAO operations but that is why we are making our request public.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: ChrisBlec:  I guess where I’m still a bit confused is how 1 CU can just make an aribtrary decision to send $500k of the DAOs money to another CU without any involvement from MKR governance.   Well it was approved already in the RWF budget. If @williamr is not willing to send it, which is his right, then we might proceed to an SPF on which MKR holder will have to decide. Latham made the legal on OFH deal and Ogier made the RWA Foundation of the HVBank deal. It is really a work along those lines. Every delay is costing to MKR holders not me. I’m fine with whatever @williamr, and then MKR holders in case of an SPF, decide.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal

content.content: Seems like a good faith exercise to ask other CUs to allocate a portion of their unused budgets to fund legal expenses (for an already approved MIP65) before alternative expense funding options. MIP65 is a strategic investment that is needed to optimize MKR’s balance sheet, the level of uninvested assets is too high and we need to move fast to reduce this drag. The cost-benefit is too high to let this opportunity keep stalling… Are there any other CUs that can step up and fund this expense?

It is key to return to profitability   So I ask all @Recognized-Delegates to please intervene in this post and make clear their PoV. I am fed up with these wars between CUs and all the political drama, and of course we can’t lose money (40k/day) in the process just for entertainment. @Recognized-Delegates Is @SebVentures right or wrong?  If he’s right please act quickly. If he’s not, please also act quickly (shutting him and/or this proposal down). We can’t have this type of drama in the forum every week.  I just can’t stand the apparent pervasive passiveness these days.

content.content: he is talking about opportunity cost. i.e. hypothetically if things went smoothly today, tomorrow DAO will already make some money. on the other hand, if things went sideways one way or another there are also costs of rushed decisions and miscalculated risks, won’t go here into details of this particular case.

content.content: pvl:  opportunity costs of rushed decisions and miscalculated risks   It is not rushing the decision or taking risk, it is working on analyzing risk instead of waiting for Godot. The SPF will take almost two months. Onboarding at a legal firm can take 2-4 weeks.

iammeeoh:  I just can’t stand the apparent pervasive passiveness these days   I would just want to dispel the impression of passiveness. This whole situation is very unfortunate and there are many things to consider. The stakes are high for everyone involved and thus any action should not be rushed, but considered against the best information available. Rest assured that many are involved in finding solutions. That includes business continuity, as well as solving the conflict that exists between various contributors at Maker. Personally I fully understand the sense of urgency, yet I ask to have a little patience.

content.content: I understand the opportunity cost but not a big fan of proposal to override a governance decision without an onchain voting. Each CU has a mandate, limits, and budgets, and breaking such construct will have far reaching consequences. Underperforming CUs (regardless of the reason) should go through discussion and onchain voting to offboard or at least adjust.

content.content: iammeeoh:  I mean, either the projection 40k/80k from @SebVentures is pure bullshit (In which case I think he should be exposed publicly)   This is a heuristic: 500M (DC) * 3% (annualized rate currently) / 365 (days per year) = 41k opportunity cost per day Expressed as an opportunity cost. You could also think of it as a 100k investment per day (40m annualized workforce expenses / 365 days per year = 109k in a workforce whose return is underperforming by 40k thanks to organizational paralysis.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Reading the OP and the comments in the thread, and as I am passing on the governance torch I expect my comments to taken accordingly. First @SebVentures I have to say I think you and pretty much anyone still retained by CUs does a disservice by hammering on @williamr multiply and repeatedly in this fashion.  What this does is just confirm to my mind that there are many people still in the DAO that can’t or don’t understand professional courtesy and have an axe to grind, both for personal satisfaction and or political gain. So lets get some basics out of the way. “Unblocking the stalled …initiative(s)” Initiative(S!). I know @Rune has been hammering on this bond issue for quite some time, and I can’t even remember where I recently read he was ‘back dooring’ some kind of deal on this issue and/or RWF/RWA (honestly a bit hard to read between the lines anymore). My point to @iammeeoh is that MakerDAO was unlikely to just drop kick 1B worth of bonds with ONE AO out of the gate.  Hence why @SebVentures said ‘initiative(S)’.    Each one of these @christiancdpetersen could attest to takes time to hammer out the legal machinery before they can be put into place and even then governance does well to not just put these to the maximum DC initially but to some reasonable starting amount. When Maker started on the RWF adventure @SebVentures was at the helm and got some initiatives going.   @Rune effectively off-boarded @SebVentures and once the new RWF team headed by @williamr came on line they basically had to review the past, and figure out how to process into the future.   But again issues (partially political and partially people) popped up AGAIN basically putting the RWA process on hold. To be fair part of these issues stem directly from @SebVentures and also from @williamr .   So I don’t think it is fair for Seb to get up on his high horse bitching about how everything is stopped and MakerDAO is losing 40K/month due solely to Will for the following reasons:  Unless governance has already decided they would DC $1B to a single player here out of the gate we would have started smaller and probably would not be getting a full 3% on much over 100-250M.  It is more likely governance would have done multiple deals (and doing multiple Arrangers/AOs whatever would have still taken longer) and these would have been starting in the next 1-2 months (maybe). There are still going to be fees on this that are unexpected so an actual 3% ROI may be a stretch (even so 2-2.5% isn’t but then we just quibble over 40K vs. 25-30K/DAI/day) Does Maker want to get this done right (both on a RWF CU front, but also from a DAO perspective) or just toss money out there hoping it comes back? Given even the previous timelines these were not going to be on-line today but more likely once the details were implemented and governance could pass DCs etc.  I have multiple concerns here.  The first is someone else who had significant interest and stake in hiring the people we now have problems with complaining the DAO is losing money.   The second is that @williamr being hammered on while he is having medical issues and not really being given time to respond.    And the third is that somehow the 20-40K/DAI/day Maker is losing, we have been losing that for the past 6 months, also while we wait interest rates (particularly on the short end) are continuing to rise so perhaps by waiting to toss in that $1B MakerDAO is potentially going to earn more.    But I would be the first to admit this is a stretch statement as well. @Recognized-Delegates please don’t get sucked into this push me pull you, passive aggressive approach to drag you around here.   While it is disappointing to see yet a second serious hitch in MakerDAO RWF don’t fall into the trap.  Unless governance intends to actually off-board @williamr and somehow replace him and his new team you have to give him a fair chance to get his house in order and resume progress. Do not mistake what is going on here.   There is a significant push by many still contracted by the DAO to just go around Will and hire the fired team to get something done ‘fast’.   Given the very high stakes here I think it is prudent for the DAO to digest the situation before it can have any hope of continuing to make healthy strides forward.   It is unpleasant, unfortunate, and I agree is costing the DAO time and revenues, but IMO these ARE NOT valid reasons to run around Will here.

content.content: Response to the community: All deals relating to RWAs need ongoing legal and deal/risk assistance. For collateral onboarding, it’s a critical part of the process. I’m also anticipating some needs after onboarding as well. Having ongoing reliable, available, and independent third parties is important to the work at hand. Like many of you, I’d like to avoid delays in getting collateral onboarded. Today, we have a RWF-001 core unit that is responsible for providing these services. If/until governance action is taken, they are the responsible party. Other than transferring a budget, I don’t see how this proposal addresses the root cause. I appreciate Seb offering a solution but the issue is much larger. As I have mentioned, managing the work is already part of the weekly collateral meetings with the collateral stakeholders. GovAlpha is part of that team. We don’t need to create another process outside of this as it would be disruptive the teams already involved. What we need is clarity on who is going to do the work. If we need to start interviewing law and deal firms, all good but we need to know that asap. The amount of Dai in question is 500m. We can’t afford mistakes. This has to be done correctly due to the existential risk. Bonds are RWAs and they are no less complex than all of the other deals we’ve done. Please keep that in mind.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: I stick to my numbers @MakerMan which are backed by actual facts all shared in this thread. I feel we should stick to facts, problems and solutions and not going to ad hominem attacks which aren’t helpful. No one is perfect but we can try our best. The only agenda I have here it to move those projects forward for which SF put a lot of energy and, as we demonstrated, are strategic to MakerDAO. This is not breaking any MIP, nor circumventing anyone. It’s a transparent and public proposal with an identified person that can decide (or not). Looking at #governance , it seems that the problem has escalated and is going to find a solution (similar to this proposal), for MIP65 at least. We will see. Whatever solution that move things forward works for me.

content.content: @SebVentures DAO token holders can revoke approval of use of their own funds at any time. In reality, the MIP system requests broad authority to carry out a mandate, and the core unit then has discretion over how to use those funds. If things went pear-shaped in any direction, there would also be expenses associated with hurried judgments and poorly assessed risks.
